If you're not familiar with this place - think Xian with Taiwanese flavors. This place is the bomb diggity and I'm glad they're flourishing in Chelsea Market.I had the beef noodle soup and can attest that they give ample servings of meat. I was almost too stuffed to finish the meat and that almost never happens for me when I'm eating soup noodles. Usually the meat is the first thing to go, but this bowl had endless amounts of meat. In fact you could probably easily share a bowl with a friend. This is the perfect spot for a snowy/rainy day. I will be back soon to try the dan-dan noodles and more of their other soups!

I love noodles, so after seeing the great photos and reviews this was a must-try on my list while in New York! We came during lunchtime on a Saturday, and while it was decently crowded, we were able to snag a seat at the bar after ordering our food. We tried both the Tingly Cumin Lamb (dry) as well as the Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup. The thing that stood out the most about this place is that they're extremely generous with their meat portions! (which makes sense given their prices of ~$13 per item are on the high end) Their Beef Noodle soup had the perfect ratio of meat and veggies to noodles (I feel like most places give you too many noodles relative to everything else), and the meat was really tender and flavorful! Definitely one of the better beef noodle soups I've had. The Cumin Lamb on the other hand, while really delicious for the first few bites, got to be a bit overwhelming. I actually would have preferred to have less lamb and more noodles + herbs, as it ended up feeling really oily and heavy. Maybe it would have been better with the soup option, but this dish would be a pass for me if I came back again. Also, the noodles themselves are all freshly handmade (which you can watch them do!), and are pretty good, but not extraordinary.

Only that it made it a little tedious to eat.Spicy Beef Noodles in Soup- this dish was comforting and the broth was great but not as great as Xi'an. Cumin Lamb noodles in soup(mild spiciness)- Similar to the beef noodle dish with less spiciness and some really tender pieces of lamb. A very comforting dish.Overall, it was a great experience eating here in spite of the lack of proper seats to sit in and eat. We managed to get seats on the counter next to the love kitchen which was a fun spot but not the most convenient.

The only downside are the crowds and the difficulty of finding a table or seat to eat at - but for good food, it's worth the extra effort.

I was really excited to try this place, but it was really disappointing.  I got the Taiwanese beef noodle soup with hand-pulled noodles.The problem with the beef noodle soup is in the broth.  It was SUPER SUPER salty.  Instead of tasting beefiness, all I tasted was salt.  Even the acidity of the pickled mustard greens couldn't balance out the salty broth.  I wonder if the pickled mustard greens had a saltiness themselves which added to the salt in the broth.The noodles themselves were good, even though they're really more Northern Chinese "biang biang" noodles.  Taiwanese beef noodle soup usually uses thin rounded hand-pulled noodles.  I really like the noodle style Very Fresh Noodles is using even though it's not traditionally Taiwanese, but I felt the noodles were too thin and so they got soggy in the broth.This would be a two-star review, but an extra star goes to the braised beef.  The beef itself was incredible.  It was well-marbled meat with lots of tendon running through it.  They also give you a large portion of the beef to go with your soup.  It might be the best beef I've ever had in beef noodle soup.I had Ho Foods the night before, so comparing the two, Very Fresh Noodles wins the braised beef component.  Noodles and broth are definitely better at Ho Foods.Very Fresh Noodles' broth was so salty I left most of it behind.  If I want beef noodle soup again, it'll be at Ho Foods.

It was literally melt in your mouth with a bit of fat, not too stringy or tough and they give you a good amount.  There are some bok choy to help with all the heavier items as well.  The flavor of the soup is SLIGHTLY different than other places I've been to but in a good way, very flavorful.Overall, highly recommend this if you come to Chelsea market. It's worth it for sure!

If you're not looking for a comfortable eating experience and are just really wanting some damn good noodles, visit Chelsea Market, wait in line for about 20 minutes, and get Very Fresh Noodles.  I'm a huge noodle soup person and this has been on my list since the days where it was a tiny little stall in the same corner, which has now turned into a giant stall with counter space.The line here was a little outrageous on the weekend and like I said, it took about 20 minutes to order and then at least another 10+ minutes to actually get the food.  Trying to find somewhere to stand at the counter as well as some of the very limited seating around is a little stressful.  Eating the noodles themselves is quite stressful given you barely have any space to move your arms.  Very uncomfortable eating experience as you really have nowhere to put your jackets or anything and end up sweating while eating the noodles.  My sister also burned her fingers on the bowls trying to get the food to the counter.BUT - if you don't care about the experience, VFN is the real deal.  It's very similar to the food at the Xi'an chains which are almost at the top of my list, but this place is actually better.  Yes, you pay a little more, but the quality is much higher and the broth is much more flavorful than the soy sauce and water mix at Xi'an.  Noodles were the perfect consistency and there was plenty of meat and condiments in the bowl.  The spicy beef noodle soup here is one of the best hand pulled noodles in the city, in my opinion.  My sister even loved their lamb noodle soup and she is a picky eater!I hope VFN opens a real restaurant so I can sit and enjoy their delicious noodles, but until then, I'll have to visit on off days when it's a little less busy.

I will definitely be back to try the dandan noodles or have the other items on the menu again.

I was really excited to try this place, but it was really disappointing.  I got the Taiwanese beef noodle soup with hand-pulled noodles.The problem with the beef noodle soup is in the broth.  It was SUPER SUPER salty.  Instead of tasting beefiness, all I tasted was salt.  Even the acidity of the pickled mustard greens couldn't balance out the salty broth.  I wonder if the pickled mustard greens had a saltiness themselves which added to the salt in the broth.The noodles themselves were good, even though they're really more Northern Chinese "biang biang" noodles.  Taiwanese beef noodle soup usually uses thin rounded hand-pulled noodles.  I really like the noodle style Very Fresh Noodles is using even though it's not traditionally Taiwanese, but I felt the noodles were too thin and so they got soggy in the broth.This would be a two-star review, but an extra star goes to the braised beef.  The beef itself was incredible.  It was well-marbled meat with lots of tendon running through it.  They also give you a large portion of the beef to go with your soup.  It might be the best beef I've ever had in beef noodle soup.I had Ho Foods the night before, so comparing the two, Very Fresh Noodles wins the braised beef component.  Noodles and broth are definitely better at Ho Foods.Very Fresh Noodles' broth was so salty I left most of it behind.  If I want beef noodle soup again, it'll be at Ho Foods.

Finally visited again after they moved locations.  Definitely the best beef noodle soup I've had in the city.WAIT: Came on MLK Jr. Day and the line was almost to the wall.  We probably waited about 10 minutes before our food came out, they call your name so be near the window area.  ATMOSPHERE: Their new location is in the same area, they just took over the other stall that used to be there so they have both areas.  Their kitchen is open so you can see them making the noodles and the soup.  It's a pretty large kitchen area but the seating is still limited.  There is a standing counter that lines the kitchen area that can probably fit about 8-10 people and then another small standing area near the ordering line that can fit maybe 4.  There are also little window seats that can fit up to 2 people.  Overall though, the best bet is to find a table elsewhere or go downstairs to the new market area.FOOD: Got the beef noodle soup (mild).  I am thankful they have a "mild" version.  Also, for those that can't eat dairy, there is no dairy in this dish!BEEF NOODLE SOUP - the noodles are chewy and fresh.  They are just what I expect when I eat beef noodle soup with hand pulled/thick noodles.  There is also a lot in here, for someone who can eat a decent amount I was so full towards the end.  The mild still has spice in it but it's not overwhelming.  The beef is also amazing! It was literally melt in your mouth with a bit of fat, not too stringy or tough and they give you a good amount.  There are some bok choy to help with all the heavier items as well.  The flavor of the soup is SLIGHTLY different than other places I've been to but in a good way, very flavorful.Overall, highly recommend this if you come to Chelsea market. It's worth it for sure!

A fan of this food stand inside Chelsea Market. Reasons to love this place:1) Fast and convenient. 2) Friendly service.3) Fresh hand pulled noodles. 4) La Mei Tawainese Beef Noodle soup. A MUST TRY!!! *slurp slurp*5) Inexpensive, about $13 a bowl of fresh noodles.One thing I might suggest is getting some tables or seating area where people can actually eat their soup instead of trying to find a countertop to put the soup down. Even better if they can open a real restaurant...I hope you give this delicious noodles place a try. Cheers!

Saw this place on other social media, and I wanted to find out if all the postings about this place were just hypes or not. Went to this place today inside Chelsea market. We went there around 2:30 pm expecting less people. The line was pretty long but it moved pretty fast. You get to see the noodles getting prepared through the window; it was interesting to watch how freshly the noodles were being pulled, but it also served as a good quality control method. We ordered tingly cumin beef and dan dan noodles (and canned drinks). They do have bubble teas which I haven't tried. Waited few minute and the service was really fast. There is no tables to sit down just like other places inside Chelsea market. But, there is a bar (no stool) to stand up and eat, some sat on the stairway, etc.The cumin beef flat noodles were amazingly good. It wasn't too spicy because we orders regular (instead of spicy). Dan dan noodle was really spicy and there is no other option to make it milder. Portions were huge; the two Asian girls (my friend and I) couldn't finish it.Really enjoyed our late lunch :)

The noodles are amazingly chewy, thick, and should I say, bouncy? Seriously, I love that the broth sticks to the uneven texture of the noodles. With that being said, the flavors of the seasoning/broth were incomparable to Xi'an. Xi'an's being the superior flavor, Very Fresh fell short. Granted, I got the dry noodles despite the cashier recommending the broth.

If you're not looking for a comfortable eating experience and are just really wanting some damn good noodles, visit Chelsea Market, wait in line for about 20 minutes, and get Very Fresh Noodles.  I'm a huge noodle soup person and this has been on my list since the days where it was a tiny little stall in the same corner, which has now turned into a giant stall with counter space.The line here was a little outrageous on the weekend and like I said, it took about 20 minutes to order and then at least another 10+ minutes to actually get the food.  Trying to find somewhere to stand at the counter as well as some of the very limited seating around is a little stressful.  Eating the noodles themselves is quite stressful given you barely have any space to move your arms.  Very uncomfortable eating experience as you really have nowhere to put your jackets or anything and end up sweating while eating the noodles.  My sister also burned her fingers on the bowls trying to get the food to the counter.BUT - if you don't care about the experience, VFN is the real deal.  It's very similar to the food at the Xi'an chains which are almost at the top of my list, but this place is actually better.  Yes, you pay a little more, but the quality is much higher and the broth is much more flavorful than the soy sauce and water mix at Xi'an.  Noodles were the perfect consistency and there was plenty of meat and condiments in the bowl.  The spicy beef noodle soup here is one of the best hand pulled noodles in the city, in my opinion.  My sister even loved their lamb noodle soup and she is a picky eater!I hope VFN opens a real restaurant so I can sit and enjoy their delicious noodles, but until then, I'll have to visit on off days when it's a little less busy.

PROS:- Traditional hand-pulled noodles. Nothing can beat that! You can even watch them pull them in front of you via the windows.- The soup base is one of the best that I've ever had. Full of spices and lively in my mouth. It's not that spicy (I can't handle spicy food at all and this was doable as long as I had water). It's more of numbing kind of spice.- The noodles are amazing. So chewy but not too elastic. They are also super super long, which is the right way to prepare it.CONS:- Wish this place had seats since eating noodles standing is an extremely hard task (especially when the noodles are super long) but the lack of seating is the case for all of Chelsea Market so I don't take it against them.SPECIFICS:- Tingly Cumin Beef = So so good. The beef is so tender and soft, the meat basically melted in my mouth. Not at all fatty. - Tingly Cumin Lamb = The lamb was also very good. A bit more tough than the beef but that's normal. It didn't have any of the gamey smell that puts most people off lamb.

I wasn't all that hungry, but let's be honest, I don't exactly need to be hungry to order a bowl of noodles. Actually picked this place because the smell was so overwhelmingly seductive.I ordered the tingly cumin lamb noodles (dry). When I received my food I was not disappointed by the way it looked or smelled. The smell that drew me in was definitely coming from this particular dish.Overall at incredibly great experience here and the food was definitely on point. The fun part about this place is that they make noodles to order (and somewhat of entertaining spectacle behind a glass wall). The noodles were slightly under done and a little bit doughy towards the bottom of the bowl, but it didn't stop me from eating the whole thing.The staff and owner were incredibly friendly and super helpful. If I lived in New York I would definitely come back for more noodle bowls.

First impression walking past this place and seeing the name was "if they name it very fresh noodles they must not be very fresh".. it's like what you'd think walking past a donut shop with a sign that says "best donuts in America!"I was wrong. Very. So very wrong. My friend came to visit and demanded we go here because she'd heard so much about it. I owe her my everything.Noodles are so thick. So strong. Soooo chewyyyyy. Broth is strong and flavorful but still clean. I've honestly never had such good beef noodle soup, not that I've had that many. But I've never wanted beef noodle soup until now. Now I crave it. Maybe I'll get some tonight

After waiting a half hour in the freezing cold at Infinity Mirrors line, we decided to quit and get food instead. My friend and I ended up going here and it was such a wonderful decision, especially being outside for so long during the first snow fall. This place is in Chelsea Market btw.They had to install a new machine so there was a thirty minute pause for orders. The owner was very nice and offered my friend and I free boba drinks while we waited. We ended up ordering their cumin lamb and the spicy beef noodles. LOVED IT. BEWARE, do not underestimate the spice levels. I have an average spice tolerance and mild was still pretty hot.I actually never ended up finishing my noodles because I got full too quickly and it got too spicy :( I loved their noodles though. There were no places to sit so we both just stood while eating at their counter where you can watch them make the noodles in front of you. I'm definitely coming back again though. The meal cleared up my sinuses for sure.

I had come to Chelsea Market with intentions of going to my beloved Los Mariscos but as I was walking around I came across Very Fresh Noodles and my mouth was salivating. With my stomach rumbling I knew there was nothing I wanted more than a big bowl of flavorful broth with handmade noodles to fill me up. I used to think you could only get the real deal in Chinatown but these guys were hand pulling noodles right in front of us!I got the Tingly Cumin Beef soup with their traditional 'biangbiang' noodles.  It was totally satisfying and the portion is huge and so so filling. I really should have stopped 2/3 of the way into it, but those noodles were too good to leave behind. They are also very generous with the meat (probably too much meat for me).So happy there's a solid noodle place like this in the area. Great addition to Chelsea Market.

Came back again and finally got my mock duck noodles (dry)!I actually ended up preferring the taste of the soup noodles I mistakenly got last time to this, but nevertheless the texture of the noodles were as perfect as I had remembered, and an overall decent meal.The dry noodles are extremely oily and spicy (I think you can adjust the spice level in the soup but not the dry noodles), and not exactly dry but DRENCHED in oil, and impossible to finish. Chalait around the corner should thank VF Noodles because I loathe Chalait but have to get it every time I get the noodles here, to wash it down. The mock duck was weird but not bad--I didn't eat much of it and preferred the noodles. Wish there were more non-meat options on the menu, but am patient for potential future additions!***A side note: The customer service is great, and they retroactively remedied the error in my order after seeing my review, despite the fact that I was too lazy to stand in line again and get new noodles while there in person. And not to expose how much of a hater I am or anything, but I really do not like the overcrowdedness of Chelsea Market, but am easily willing to enter the hellhole it is for these noodles!

The noodle soups were extremely good. They packed our bowls with meat, and both the lamb and the beef were very tender and flavorful. The broths were hearty, salty, and amazing tasting, and the noodles were cooked really well. Honestly, I felt the food here was better than anything you could get outside the country. Now that said, I was a bit wary that they were serving scorching hot food in plastic bowls. Not an expert in food safety, but I feel that's not the best practice.

Been seeing their video trending on social media, and I happened to be in the area, so I had to try it!  When arrived, there was a long line, which was always signal a good sign!  In front of the cooks, there's a glass wall filled with people slurping their bowl of noodles and sniffling from the heat of the soup, I was excited!  We had ordered the following:Tingly Cumin Lamb - signature "biangbiang" noodles (pulled, smashed, and ripped) seasoned with a heap of cumin, Sichuan peppercorns, chili oil, celery, and fresh herbs - the bowl of broth and cumin lamb filled with uncut long as your body noodles was so damn delicious, I wish I had ordered two!  The flavor profiles were booming!  I could not stop eating, especially in the cold weather, it hit all the right spots!Definitely worth stopping and getting a bowl if you are in Chelsea market!

Not a fan of the crowded and touristy Chelsea Market.. but I'll suck it up for some delicious hand pulled Taiwanese beef noodle soup.At around $12 for a bowl of noodles, it's certainly not your typical Chinatown hole-in-the-wall noodle joint. There's a hefty crowd at even odd eating times of the day and you have to hover over other people eating in order to snag their seats.The noodles had just the right amount of chew and the portion size was definitely filling. The broth was very hearty and flavorful, but too salty for me - my only complaint. I imagine that a traditional Taiwanese beef noodle soup has a lighter broth that I can drink straight from the bowl.Definitely recommended to noodle and xi'an food lovers! Would 100% come back to try their other menu items - hopefully they're less salty!#sendnoodz

Solid 3.5. Pretty tasty noodles handpulled right in front of you. While the cumin lamb and Taiwaneese beef noodle soup looked super delicious, I ordered the very spicy dan dan mian noodles w/ pork ($12) and asked them to make it extra spicy. The noodles standout with a nice springy chew. They came in this kinda  overly oily peanut butterish sauce spiked with scallions and broad beans. Pretty tasty but not very spicy tho. Very instagram worthy foodwise tho with the noodle shot.

Enjoyed my cumin beef soup.  It was worth the wait.  The flavor was superb.  The broth and meat are fatty so you might want to eat vegan a few days before.   The fresh herbs and green onions we're a great fresh add.   Looking around everyone's noodles we're of different thickness.  Watching the noodle maker, each one shape is different.  Does he ever get tired of pounding noodles? The noodles are in the top ten ever tasted.

The name isn't a lie, these noodles are fresh. If you like noodles and spice you'll probably be a fan. Spicy tingly cumin lamb noodles: 6/10 spice. Pretty similar to X'ian Famous Foods version. Maybe a touch spicier. Taiwanese beef noodle soup: 7/10 spice. Not a traditional version but still good. The noodles are thick and wide, the beef is tender for the most part, and there's plenty of vegetables. Broth is deep red and rich and satisfying. Dan dan mian: 8/10 spice. Yeah these are pretty spicy. It says so in the name. But the noodles are perfectly chewy, there is a generous amount of pork, and the peanuts/beans are ridiculously crunchy. This is the dan dan mian for people who actually want spice (compared to Han Dynasty's version which are tasty but not spicy at all). Pro tip: get a horchata from Los Tacos no. 1 before consuming, it's the perfect cool down. My only criticism is that the bar where you stand and eat is consistently dirty. Wipe that shit down more often. Thanks!

Best hand-pulled noodles in NYC. They initially were just a pop-up in Chelsea Market but got so popular, they got a permanent spot. Glad to see they have a bigger space with more workers now to counteract the long lines.The Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup is their star here. The noodles are so chewy and the broth has so much flavor. Not to mention they don't skimp on meat! I also really enjoyed their Dan Dan noodles which always comes spicy. I was definitely sweating a bit but it hurt so good.Like most of Chelsea Market, there's not much seating but there are standing tables where you can gaze at the kitchen prepping the food. This was actually my last meal in NYC before moving back to SF.

A super popular spot tucked in the back corner of the Chelsea Market. During the lunchtime rush I waited in line for about 10 minutes before placing my order. It was ready in a couple minutes -not bad!Of the 4 noodle dishes/soups on their menu, I ordered the Tingly Cumin Lamb soup that uses Sichuan peppercorns which have a cool kind of spice. With chili oil, celery, herbs, and super tender lamb, this noodle soup is such a prize! When they ask if you want it spicy, say yes!!! The heat's obvious but not overwhelming and it makes the dish so tasty. The hand-pulled noodles made right in front of me were flat with a perfect springy texture. Since they come rather long, they're a little messy to eat but it worked out okay despite my mediocre chopstick skills.You can eat standing along their long-ass counter (there's a high turnover of diners) while watching the magic behind the glass or at some windows nearby. You can request a lid for your bowl and a bag if you can't finish your meal. I soup-er recommend this place!

When I was here just a few months ago, they were still in their little booth in the far back corner. Now they've taken over the lot in front of their previous booth and they're double the size. That's double the view of their kitchen magic!Also new, and very much welcomed, is a new menu item: "Very Spicy Dan Dan Mian". It's actually spicy! This may be the best bowl of dan dan noodles I've ever had in the city, seriously! Like I said, the dish is actually spicy (too often I get "spicy" dishes that aren't spicy at all), the sauce is meaty and nutty, the meat is seasoned well, the noodles are chewy, and the toppings are a great compliment to everything else. Gotta toss in another star for blowing my mind with this recently added dish.

Instant love. The menu is super limited and that is perfect with me.I had the beef soup with beautifully tender braised beef, (very) fresh noodles and delicious broth. You can choose either mild or spicy, though mild is perfect (it made me sweat). They have 2 other soups, lamb and vegetarian. I was there for lunch time on a Wednesday and the line went quick, these guys are super fast and have a great line system to get your yummy soup to you in as soon as possible! definitely check them out!

Bumped into this place by randomly seeing people eating the "Real Chinese Noodle" in Chelsea Market. Very Fresh Noodles is a very popular place for decent Chinese noodles. All the noodles are made fresh. They have two people making the hand-pulled noodles just right in front of me, making me feel like back to home, so sweet and authentic. You can see the flatness, wideness and tenderness of the noodles face to face, so cool! I ordered the Tingly Cumin Lamb Soup that has the traditional Sichuan sauce and broth. The lamb meat are fresh and tasty as well. I really like the Chili taste of the soup, spicy but not too much, while having many veggies in it.Recommend this place to ppl who just did museum visits or who just finished one-day shopping. It's so perfect for a quick dinner, but a great opportunity to have traditional Chinese noodles.

I recently tried the spicy dan dan noodles, and I'm glad I did.  I would say it's probably one of my top two favorite dan dan noodles in the city.  The noodles are chewy; the sauce has the perfect balance of savory, sweet, and heat (not too sweet), not to mention plenty of meat (and the meat isn't overly fatty); and the fried fava beans add a nice crunch too.  It's not as spicy as I expected, but it is definitely delicious.

I was exploring food options in Chelsea market and found this booth away and in the back. The menu consist of 4 types of noodle dishes, one of them being vegan. I ordered the vegan noodles with mock duck ($13). You can get it either spicy/not spicy and dry/wet. I decided to go for not spicy and wet. While I waited for the food to come out, I got to see the cooks pulling their freshly handmade noodles. It was pretty entertaining. I got my noodles with mock duck meat (which looked and tasted like seitan) celery, mustard greens, and herbs drenched in a mushroom broth + chili oil. The noodles were sooooo soft yet chewy. The broth was surprisingly flavorful. The broth wasn't 'burning my mouth' spicy but there's a unique spicy flavor from the peppercorn as well. The mock meat was ok, it reminded me of my mom's vegan dish that consisted of a meat substitute from a food can she bought at an Asian super market lol. Other than that, I love how restaurants, like this in particular, are spreading the word about how vegan food can be as flavorful and tasty. Definitely a must try when visiting.

Hands down, this is one of the best things I've ever eaten. My sister and I got the La Mei Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup, and it was EVERYTHING. The noodles are literally made right in front of you, the beef was like butter it was so tender, and the broth was rich and flavorful. 20/10 would recommend this place

Came in on a cloudy chilly day in nyc and what better soup to eat on a cold day? The beef noodle soup was the warmth to my soul, I've enjoyed watching the employees hand pull the noodles, cutting the beef in chunks then combining it all in one hot delicious soup! The soup was spicy which I prefer, the beef was soft and tender and the noodles were cooked to perfection! Definitely a must try if your in the area!

Hands down, the best noodles I have ever had in my life. The freshness and chewiness of their noodles is unrivaled. Now I know what it's like to eat noodles that are freshly made right in front of you. This little shop inside Chelsea Market is a must visit for any noodle fanatics.Tingly Beef Noodles (dry) - I've already mentioned the amazing noodles, but the beef in this dish is also so tender and juicy. Watch out, when they say it's tingly, they aren't kidding. Halfway through the bowl I could feel that mala (numbing) tingling all over my mouth.The line can be long, but the speed at which they make the noodles is SO fast. There was a long line when I visited on a Friday night. (10 or so people in line), but my noodles were out within 5 minutes. You can also watch as they make the noodles and soup right in front of you on their all glass walls around the kitchen. I would go here all the time if I lived in New York!

I enjoyed very fresh noodles! I came here because I wasn't able to make it to Xian Famous Foods before I left the city, and Very Fresh Noodles was much closer to the train I had to take.  Their menu selection is a bit limited, but it's nice because they have vegan options which I think is pretty rare for a Taiwanese restaurant.  I got the Dan Dan Noodles with pork, one of my favorite Taiwanese dishes.  It was good! The noodles were fresh and QQ (For non-Taiwanese people, I think the translation is kind of like chewy), and it was spicy!! It had a lot of cucumbers and a healthy amount of cumin, so beware if you're not into that kind of spice.  It did get a bit oily towards the bottom, but what good Taiwanese restaurant doesn't.  I'll have to try the beef noodle soup next time, but I would suggest this spot if you're in the area, though I do prefer Xian for some fresh hand pulled noodles.

Holy crap. I have never had such fresh chewy yummy noodles and because so many people recommended this place i had to see it through. The line moves fast and you get your food fast afterwards because of their assembly line style of service. The beef noodle soup (spicy) was just spicy enough to make my nose run, but it was completely worth it. Tasted so good and fresh.

When we dropped by Very Fresh Noodles last weekend for the first time, they had four different noodle options on their soft opening menu. They all sounded good, but we went straight for the "very spicy dan dan mian" because we love trying dan dan mian all over the city. Even though it was in the name, they warned us again when ordering that it would be very spicy. I figured there would be a good amount of spice, but they weren't kidding. That was probably the spiciest dan dan mian I've ever had. If you can take the spice though, it was delicious.All the noodles are, as their name says, made fresh, and you can watch them making them through the window that lines the standing counter where you can eat your noodles. The freshness shows in the texture of the noodles, as they had just the right amount of chewiness. It was a little expensive at $12 for one bowl, but there was a plentiful amount of pork, cucumber, scallions, fried broad beans (something you don't see in all dan dan mian), and spices to go along with the noodles. I would get that again, although I'd like to try the other options on the menu first, especially the cumin lamb noodles.As for where in the market they're located, they're right by one of the entrances on 15th Street, so if you're heading straight there for some noodles, save yourself from the ridiculous crowds and traffic in the rest of the market and just go in straight from the street.

One less star because of their price! Taste, texture, and portion size are excellent! I like how they keep their menu concise and simple! Lines are long but move fast. Because it's inside Chelsea market, it's hard to find seating as well! I really hope they can open a small, more reasonably priced branch in queens, to coexist with all the other hand pulled noodle shops in elmhurst!

After you order, the noodles take a while to actually be ready, but they're worth the wait! The noodles are super chewy and there's something about working for your noodles, that makes them extremely satisfying! They do not exaggerate when they say VERY FRESH noodles, because they legit make the noodles on the spot, right in front of your eyes! I got the Cumin Lamb Dry Noodles (because they were sold out of the Beef Noodle ones when we got there) and it was quite tasty. Super sauce-y with a good amount of aromatic spices to really drench the noodles in, plus lots and lots of lamb! The kitchen is VERY generous with the meat! I did wish that the sauce was spicier to add an extra level of yummy dimension to the noodles. But otherwise, it was quite tasty.I've eaten a LOT of noodles from Xi'An Famous Foods, and I think the greatest contrast is the spice level. Xi'An is way spicier but less generous with the sauce + meat. So Fresh Noodle is a great choice for the spice-averse! Recommend for some of the seriously freshest noodles in the city!

Very Fresh Noodles is located in the very busy Chelsea Market. It's tucked nicely in the corner, but you can't miss it because their smells fill the area up. When I went on a weekend, there was a line and it took about 20 minutes to get my food. While you wait, you can also see the chefs work their magic in the windows. You can see the live the making of the noodles made in front of your very eyes. (It really is very fresh). FOOD: When I went around 12 PM, they had already run out of the lamb noodles. Instead, I went for the vegan noodles with broth ($13). The broth soup consists of noodles, imitation meat, and tons of vegetables. The broth, even though vegan, was super rich and flavorful. You could taste how fresh the noodles were. The unique thing about the dish is the use of the noodle making technique. The soup contains a single thick noodle that was continually kneaded. SERVICE: Once you finish ordering, you can wait on the side for your food. They systemically write your number on the bowl and fill the orders. It took about 15 minutes to actually get my food once I ordered. You can wait agonizingly on the side as they call your name. Even though there was a 20 minute wait in total, they worked so fast and efficiently for the number of orders they were receiving. ATMOSPHERE: Since this is a booth, I had to find my own seating in Chelsea Market. It can get very crowded and tourist filled since its right next to the high line. I took my food outside and actually found a small park to eat my food at since the weather was so nice. They even had plenty of tables and chairs. (14th Street Park, it's right outside Chelsea Market). OVERALL: I would definitely come back if I'm ever in the area. Worth the try if you are a fan of traditional Taiwanese noodles.

Sometimes, things happen for a reason. I've wanted to try Very Fresh Noodles for a while, but my treks to Chelsea Market are almost always during peak hours, so I'm spending more time there navigating through tourists taking photos, causing me to say, "Nuts to this! I'm just going to go to Los Tacos No.1 and getting the F out of here!" On a Monday evening around 7, my friends and I ended up here after deciding to give a local restaurant another try after a sub-par first visit spurred an invite from their management team; see my two-star review from 2/5/2018, haaa. Long story very short, we ended up leaving there before ordering and needed some comfort food to soothe our hanger. One friend wanted noodles, and Very Fresh Noodles popped into her head. IT SAVED US.The menu is small, but it sure makes it easy to choose! I certainly don't say that punitively. Plus, once La Mei Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup caught me eye, so how could I say I wanted to eat somewhere else? Ha! Along with that soup (spicy or mild options available), Tingly Cumin Beef and Lamb noodle options were on the menu, along with a vegan noodle dish with mock duck, mushrooms, and bok choy. While I can not say that I tried my friends' spicier dishes - me and spice are NOT best friends - I can certainly speak to the rich comfort that the mild Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup provided me. The ample cilantro and green onions sprinkled on top occasionally cleansed my palate as I worked through the rich red broth, melt - in - your - mouth beef shanks, and garlicky mustard greens. For those totally adverse to spice, be warned: even the mild has the tiniest kick to it. Your nose may get a little runny, but it's absolutely worth it. As for my friends' spicy dishes, their bowls were polished pretty clean after consumption, so I think I can very safely attest that everything at Very Fresh Noodles is delectable. A good soup always wins, no matter what its country of origin. A lot of comfort comes from doughy hand-pulled Biangbiang noodles and a rich broth. Very Fresh Noodles is DEFINITELY on my radar for future visits.

Finally, a place that lives up to its name. Could also be called:Very Sumptuous MealPillowy NoodlesHow Have I Never Tried This BeforeThe noodles are thick and heavenly, like a wider counterpart to drunken noodles, and they're pulled right in front of you. The beef is so soft - like brisket - and perfectly sized chunks that just fall apart as you eat them.The massive branch of bok choy is a delicious attempt to seem healthy.And the broth is not too thick, yet so flavorful.The size of the bowl is one of the best parts. I was stuffed halfway in and heated up the rest for lunch. The amazingness continues. Soup: The Sequel.5 stars!!!!!!!!

These noodle bowls are a hot mess to eat but SO worth it. Prepare your body for some sweat, tears, burning, sniffling, and taste bud heaven. There are a few options for a soup base (ex. Sichuan cumin style, Taiwamese beef noodle soup style, and a veggie option) the protein is beef or lamb and you can choose spice level. Highly recommend the Cumin beef or lamb. Of course the STAR of the show is the ridiculously long freshmade noodles. It takes several bites to reach the end and are a bit of a hazard to slurp as their large surface area sprays soupy goodness everywhere. The veggies in the soup are a great crunchy fresh complement to the rich soup and chewy noodles. The beef was incredibly tender and flavorful, truly unique to this style of noodle soup. I honestly blacked out during the meal. There was so much spice, tongue burning, and soup bowl balancing going on I tuned completely into the meal and zoned in. This will forever be my go to in the Chelsea market

#SendNOODZFor $13 you get dinner AND a show! This was on the top of my list of New York must eats and it did not disappoint. I got the cumin lamb dry and it had tons of flavor, the noodles were perfectly al dente QQ and the flavor was spot on. When we stopped by on a Saturday around 3:00 pm I thought there would be a long line but there was absolutely no wait at all!!A NY must!! =)

Very fast and friendly service, however, I thought the noodle dish was just ehhh. I ordered the tingly cumin beef dish (dry). The beef was definitely cooked perfectly, however, I felt the seasonings overpowered the dish and I couldn't really taste the meat or flavor of the noodles. In my opinion, for a good noodle dish, you should be able to taste the freshness and quality of the noodles. The sauce completely kills the noodles and all I tasted was cumin (yes yes, i know the name has cumin in it, but I should be able to enjoy the dish without actually eating complete herbs).My wife ordered the La Mei Taiwanese Beef noodle soup. Hers was good and wasn't overpowering like mine, but I felt it was still missing something. Maybe more veggies? The beef was basically the same type of beef in my dish, but the broth did diminish the overpowering seasoning a bit, so it was actually perfect flavoring.Overall: For so many places in NY, I don't see myself really coming back here.

JUST TAKE MY MONEY!! I would not mind eating this 3 times a day. I'm not a fan of wide or thick noodles bc quite frankly I just don't like it and the extra starch/ flour makes soups thick. Their noodles are wide but it's not thick probably cuz they smack the crap out of it lolll. I ordered the Taiwanese beef noodle soup. The beef was so tender! It actually melted in my mouth! It's so tender that it breaks into several pieces when you pick it up too quickly with your chopsticks. The broth is everything I ever asked for! It's seasoned well and it's not greasy! They even add sour preserved cabbage in it (that's pretty authentic Taiwanese beef noodle bro), anyways it cuts the creaminess of the broth so you don't get sick of it. Another worthy mention is their cucumber salad! I ordered 4 to go lmfaooo. It's like candy; it's sweet yet sour and a slight kick from the hot oil! It's so crunchy too omg! Yeah just try it, the thing is like $4 or something.

It is not a hidden gem anymore...and hands down it's one of the best place in Chelsea Market. It's located at a corner across from the seafood place towards the middle of the building, oh...IT'S A CORNER GEM! But everyone seems to know about it because there is ALWAYS a line. It is so popular among all nationalities which is interesting but awesome! The reason people love this place is probably because of the spices. Sichuan peppercorn and loads of cumin in the soup base. You can choose mild or spicy. Each bowl is just too satisfying. Although it is on the oily side due to the chili, it certainly would leave you so fulfilling - both the portion and the taste. They have what I would say is the CLOSEST authentic TAIWANESE beef noodle soup in town (Not comparing to Flushing in Queens). If you want to get a taste of the Taiwanese style noodle soup, GET IT HERE. It's got picked mustard, cilantro, scallions, and the braised beef that melts into your tongue. For Taiwan natives, just do know that they put more cumin and Sichuan peppercorn into this broth because it's their style.I have to credit the dude (owner) who always makes the "biang biang" noodles. From beginning when they opened the shop to now, it's still him! He has became the true master of making THE ART. I see that he tries to make it amusing and artsy...which makes the whole experience of ordering food from there great.

It's inside Chelsea Market.  They are known for their beef noodle soup.  The noodles are hand-pulled too.  The noodles have a good chew, but don't dawdle or your noodles will soften.  The beef is very tender (think all-day crock pot).  You can get the beef noodle soup either regular or spicy.  I went with spicy, and it wasn't too spicy.  It was a good amount of beef and noodle.  I did not get a chance to try lamb cumin noodles.  I didn't get a chance to get to Xi'an, so I can't compare it. As of fall 2017, it looks like they are remodeling/expanding, so for now they are in a small cart in the back.

Amazing noodle spot. Their name does not lie--you will get very fresh noodles and that's that. What more can I say? The beef noodle soup was extremely fresh tasting and light, despite all the hot chili oil floating at the top of the soup. Most places skimp on the meat topping but not here! They are very generous with the meat topping (spicy braised beef), you'll get a mouthful of meat in every bite, which I very much appreciate in a hot bowl of noodle soup.The lamb cumin soup was equally as tasty and satisfying. Next time I will have to try it dry (without soup), since I did find the broth a little heavier with all the flavors coming from the lamb. Definitely check this place out. You will leave overly satisfied, full, and entertained from watching the live noodle pulling!

Yes, this place is popular and hyped.My friends and I came here on a late Saturday afternoon and we were informed it would take a 45 minute wait to get our food due to them being backed up. We decided to stay because my friend insisted it'd be worth it.About an hour passed and we FINALLY got our food. We got the cumin lamb noodle, spicy beef noodle, and vegan noodle.Since we were hella hungry, the first few bites had us like OMGGGG SO GOOOD. After awhile though, we realized the noodles were too heavy with too much oil. The noodles itself were fresh and thick but a little hard to eat because it was extremely long. The lamb and beef pieces were good. Essentially my problem was with the broth LOL. Too heavy, too thick, and too oily that it sort of ruined the noodles for me. Also, prices were about $13-14 per bowl so it's not cheap. I probably won't be back here as there are other fresh noodle places to find in NY!

Since I came to NY, I was craving noodles, like big time. Thankfully, here in the big Apple the choices are abundant! This little joint is located inside the Chelsea market and with all the food options available in there, this place always had a line. When I say little, I am being literal. I don't think the place has more that 200sqr feet and that's pretty much their kitchen. You must take your order to go and enjoy it at the outside comunal tables, standing or like me; just to go. The menu is very simple and straight forward; 3 different noodle options that can be dry or in a soup. They will take your order, name and that's it. You can see the magic happening as you wait for it. I went with the Vegan noodle option with "fake" duck meat. I got to the apartment and depend my order extremely excited and after the 1st taste I just went bananas! That broth was just delicious  full of flavor and most definitely fresh; The veggies, the "fake" meat which I would eat every day and of course the noodles . This was happiness inside a spon for over half and hour; yeah, I took my time and I'm very happy about it  My noodles crave was satisfied and my taste buds simply enlightened.

Had to check this place out from all the hype on instagram. Honestly, there's nothing too special about these noodles, there wasn't much flavor and it's not comparable to the hand pulled noodles in flushing. You definitely need extra hot sauce, it'll add a kick to the dish. I would probably skip this stand.

The noodles are certainly fresh, and the spice is BALLER. Food: 3.75   Taste-4   Presentation- 3.5Atmosphere/Aesthetic: 4Service: 3.5Price/Value: 4Most dishes are between $10 and $15, and we got the Dan Dan Mian. Very fresh meat and noodles, decent portion size (we didn't finish it), and the spice is true to the dish. I gave the atmosphere a 4 just because it's located in Chelsea Market, which is a very posh eating place.Seating can be hard to come across though, as there's just a little bar area for Very Fresh Noodle. Line is really long but moved at a decent pace, and the food comes out really quickly. Price is about the same as you can find at other places, but the noodle dishes here are better! So def check this place out if you want noodles in Chelsea Market.

This is an amazing place for vegetarians. They have a vegan noodle option that comes loaded with seitan, veggies, and a vegan mushroom broth that is extremely rich and flavourful. The portions are enormous and can be split with another person if you are not a huge eater. Everything is seasoned well. The seitan ("mock duck") is great. The food is fresh and made to order right in front of you. I found the broth to be a bit heavy and oily, but overall it was delicious. It is one of the best vegetarian soup broths I've had. This place is a great addition to the city and adds some competition to the other really good hand pulled noodle place in Manhattan.

The beef noodle soup is good I guess, but not really "Taiwanese" noodle soup.Very flavorful the soup base is almost a bit too think/heavy.Noodle is good, beef was very tender too, melted in my mouth!But $14 for a bowl of noodle soup? Not sure if it's worth it.This stand literally is the most popular one in Chelsea market (other than Lobster Place) on a Friday night all other stand was empty but this one has a long line!

The first thing that I did when I got to New York was frantically search for the best places to get hand pulled noodles. I came across Very Fresh Noodles inside Chelsea Market and lucky for me, there was no line. I've heard that this place can get very crowded during lunch hours so I would recommend either coming here earlier or later during the day (I went for dinner and there was no line).I ordered the Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup and chose the "spicy" option. It definitely was not as spicy as I expected...Nevertheless, it was delicious! The noodles were perfectly firm and had a nice chew to them with every bite. The beef was also nicely cooked and fell apart in your mouth--so soft!I dreamed of these noodles days after I ate them. If I'm ever in the area again, I will definitely be returning to Very Fresh Noodles.

I got the Tingly Cumin Beef soup (spicy) and it was so delicious! After each bite I was loving it more and more. The beef was so tender and juicy, and words can't describe how yummy the noodles were.They were out of chopsticks when I went so it was a bit hard to eat the way I would prefer, but they offered me a fork and it was fine. Not enough seating, was annoying to eat this standing up.

Ordered the Taiwanese beef noodle soup - noodles had good chewy consistency, good portion of tender beef, lots of herbs and soup had a lot of good flavor without being too salty. A bit pricey at $14+ including tax. Super small set up in the back of Chelsea market. It's alway impressive how little space people need in NYC to run a food operation. There was no wait when I went on a Friday afternoon around 3pm but I've seen a long wait on the weekend before. It looks like they're building a bigger space right next door which will hopefully alleviate the wait time.

So far this place might be one of my favorites for noodles. They are nice and chewy and are so consistent with every bite. The different flavors of the for the dry and soupy noodles are all so good. We usually always try a veggie dish assuming it will taste a little less flavorful, however even the vegetarian dishes are so good! It's a small place that doesn't have seating and it's located in Chelsea's market. There's usually a pretty long line for these guys! If you're in the area and looking for some flavorful noodles his is the place to go.

Very Fresh NoodlesVery Very GoodVery Very Very Longgg LineJust as the place name says here literally (and fortunately), the noodle quality reflects just that. My tingly cumin beef noodle is really freshly made & cooked a la minute, topped with generous meat portions and served with lots of aromatic vegetables.  Perfectly chewy, meaty and savory - just how I liked my noodle cooked. Yet, unfortunately just like any other popular food place at NYC, great food will always translates to longgg lines. I probably waited around 45 mins+ at 1 PM Sunday just to get my own noodles and to finally appease my hunger for noodles.Worth the money? YesWorth the calory? YesWorth the wait? No..if you are in a rushNevertheless.. I will come back!

Service was quick. Not too busy on a weekday afternoon.Food was good but nothing to write home about. It's fun to watch like how the Facebook videos set it up to look like. Soup was a little oily, and I didn't get a huge flavor profile from it. The noodles were fresh as the name goes. Probably better to eat it there rather than take it to go.

Inside Chelsea Market.Got the Spicy Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup. The beef was extremely tender and the broth was good. Fresh noodles are always great and has that amazing chewy texture. Portion is decent for its price but it's not cheap by any means. The soup was overpowered by spice and not very BNS-y.

I first learned about this place on through videos on social media, so it was pretty exciting getting to try this place out for myself! It's located within Chelsea Market, so it's very easy to find. I thought the line would be super long and out the door since we went during prime lunchtime (1pm) on a beautiful Saturday afternoon, but the boyfriend and I definitely waited less than 30 minutes.Atmosphere:It's fast and convenient with a chic storefront. You can watch them make the noodles, which is pretty cool. Because it's in Chelsea Market, the seating was pretty limited, but we were lucky enough to score a little spot to sit by the window.Food:We shared the mild La Mei Tawainese Beef Noodle soup. For $13, you could probably get a lot more elsewhere, but their shop basically went viral, so I understand the upcharge. The veggies were fresh, and the bok choy was crunchy. The soup was just okay to me, but my boyfriend liked it more. I wish there was a little more flavor to it, but I was afraid to get the spicy one. The beef was super tender and easily fell apart in our mouths. To me, the noodles were the star of the show. 12/10 would recommend those noodles in all my soups. Like the video, they were super long and slurpable. But the video doesn't capture the soft, chewiness of the noodles. They are indeed, very fresh noodles. Overall, we ate a warm, hearty, savory, and delicious bowl of soup perfect for a chilly day.

Worth the stop. Fresh wide thinly pulled noodles in beef broth soup filled with some green bok choy. Broth was savory with a vinegar like-tangy taste. Very tender beef. $14 for a bowl, a little on the pricey end and worth it.Quick service and had to find seating on the side to slurp down the noodle soup.

Located in Chelsea's Market; super small stall in the corner. The line to order is by the "kitchen" and there's another longer line afterwards to wait for the food. It is basically packed all day. They take orders quickly and say it's a 15-20 minute wait. We ordered at 6pm on a Sunday and it took almost 40 minutes. Small menu and costs ~ $13 for a bowl of noodles. Ordered the lamb noodles in soup. Definitely recommend in soup, not dry! Much more flavorful. Beef noodle soup is also a popular choice. There is a moderate or spicy level. The noodles are handpulled in front of you with a glass wall so you can watch. Very fresh! The noodles itself were delicious, chewy and not soggy. The soup was spicy and just the right amount of flavor. People compare it to Xian Famous Foods - its definitely spicier, has more of a kick and flavor in my opinion. This one is there and doesn't overwhelm as much. This place is also a bit pricier than Xian Famous Foods. Overall good experience but knocked down a star because of the extremely long wait and the price.

Fresh chewy flavorful noodles! Quite filling too! The price is around $12 a bowl and you can get it with soup or dry. I tried the vegan option with soup and my BF had the Taiwanese beef noodles with soup.  Although mine was good but the BEEF in his bowl was AMAZINGLY TENDER!!! And so flavorful! Highly recommend trying that one for the first time!If you see a line, don't get discouraged. It'll move fast and you'll get your food quickly. They have a bar but no chairs so you can either eat standing or order your noodles to-go and find a table with chairs inside the Chelsea Market!

I had seen this place on Instagram a few times and had been interested ever since. I was in the city and since my bf and I had some time to kill in the city one Sunday, we decided to stop in Chelsea market for an afternoon lunch-- I made a bee-line to VFN. When I arrived, there were about 7-9 people in front of me in line, so I had plenty of time to look over their very modest menu. There are only a handful of options as they specialize in the fresh noodles (duh). The set up is very, very quaint-- one guy making and hand pulled the noodles, one girl assembling the bowls, another guy taking orders, and another girl cleaning dishes. With that said, the wait time was quite long. Though there weren't many ppl in front of me to order, there were a lot of ppl in front of me waiting on their food, so I wound up waiting about 20-25 mins for my food. I ordered the dry cumin noodles with beef. Nice size, definitely more expensive than it would be in somewhere like Chinatown, but hey, it's Chelsea. The noodles were chewy and the sauce was well developed. I asked for spicy and it wasn't but it wasn't a deal breaker. If you go here, be prepared to wait!

I went with the vegan duck biang biang soup, and while the noodles were definitely 5 stars, the broth was just way too salty and oily, so that brought down the average. It started out ok but about halfway through it was just too much to handle. I could have done without the fake duck too--it had a weird texture, more similar to wet cardboard than meat. Honestly I'd have been happier with some tofu, not sure what the deal is with the imitation meat. I would probably recommend the dry noodles, though I can't say for sure without actually trying them myself. The whole operation surely is a fun sight with the chef hand-pulling and tearing fat noodles way in the back, so the all glass kitchen definitely scores some style points. If they balanced out the broth, this place would be an easy 5 stars!

-thick chewy-ish noodles-they were out of beef early on a Friday evening-tingly cumin lamb was barely spicy-lamb was a little dry (but no gamey odor)-almost no seating, like most places in Chelsea marketI came here with two friends, and we all got the tingly cumin lamb as they were out of beef and only had three noodle options on the menu. It was much less spicy than the noodles at Xian famous foods (the obvious comparison I guess, though those aren't exactly authentic - Xian's noodles are also thinner) but overall it was still fine. It was quite busy and we waited about ten minutes for our order. The guy taking orders was super personable and friendly - I was very impressed. The highlight of this experience was probably when someone asked if they had gluten free options and he responded "no, we love our gluten here." A close second was when a kid asked if they had just noodles with nothing else added and he replied "no, that wouldn't taste very good."Previously (well over a year) ago I'd been here once gotten the vegan duck one and I have a vague recollection of it being too salty and/or oily and not wanting to get it again, but I liked the noodles and remember them being better on my first visit. The menu also doesn't seem to have expanded since then, but their popularity definitely has!

Who doesn't love a hearty bowl of Taiwanese beef noodle soup, especially when you get to watch your noodz get pulled and made right in front of you?! Amazing, I know. It's even better when it's in your belly. If you're in Chelsea Market, you should definitely come here. Even if you're not in Chelsea Market, you should come here anyways. If INSIDER food recommends it, that means it must be amazing. Very Fresh Noodles is a small stand tucked away on the side of Chelsea Market. It's a stand that's constantly buzzing with people around, trying to watch the noodz get stretched, smacked, pulled, and cooked before ending up perfectly QQ in your bowl of delicious soup. FOOD: Taiwanese Beef Noodle Soup - I personally love a good bowl of hearty beef noodle soup, but it's hard to find it done right. The noodles aren't QQ enough or the broth isn't thick and flavorful enough or the beef isn't tender and chewy. However, this bowl of beef noodle soup is made just about perfectly. The bowl will set you back $14, but it's actually way more filling and hearty than it seems. The long wide noodle is literally never ending as you start on your bowl of soup, which is good because it's so fresh and a good consistency. The spicy version of the soup definitely has a good kick to it, so be prepared with some water. It also has a rich flavor of beef and spice and everything good in the world. I was most surprised about the beef because it was so tender and juicy and there was a lot of it compared to many other bowls of beef noodle soup I've had.TLDR: come here for some delicious soup with amazing noodles and lots of super tender beef chunks. it's definitely worth the $14 because you'll be full for many many hours after.

Tucked inside the already crowded Chelsea Market was this Very Fresh Noodles kiosk serving freshly pulled noodles with the tangy smell of beef and lamb all smother together (don't get me wrong, it smelled awesome). I was already sweating like a dog trying to find this place so getting a soup noodle was not ideal for me, so instead we went and got the Tingly Cumin Beef (dry noodle). I did not regret it at all, the dry noodle was still very saucy with the beef just swimming in the noodle, and omgee the beef was so tender that it almost melts in my mouth! The flavors were powerful but not intense, the spice was kicky but also not too much that I'll need to drink water after every bite. Definitely something worth trying/coming back for if you're in the area or maybe even not in the area!Please note as I mentioned above that this is a kiosk restaurant, so there's no chairs or tables there for you to eat. But you are at Chelsea Market so just walk around and look for somewhere you can chow down your noodles in peace.

I had a lot of high hopes for this restaurant but it is just not that good... The wait at rush hours is like 20-30 mins which is a lot for Chelsea Market average. The way they hand made their noodles is more like the Xi-an type of noodles, but the way they cook it is more for regular noodles. So the end result is like a weird mix. The portion is super tiny for the price. Not worth it.

Got the spicy tingly beef soup, noodles are pleasingly chewy although it's not very spicy. Little heavy on green onion but overall delicious. Will definitely be back for some of the other menu options. At $13 it's more expensive than Chinatown, but to be expected in Chelsea Market.

Very fresh indeed.The noodles are made right then and there and they are so delicious! Super long too between. The braised beef was tender and flavorful. The pieces just melt in your mouth. They taste better than Xi'an!I had the spicy Taiwanese beef noodle soup and loved it. Noodles - check. Beef - check. Broth - check. The only thing is that it wasn't spicy.My husband had the dry tingly beef noodles and although the noodles and beef were good, the sauce got a bit too sour after several bites. The cumin wasn't as strong as Xi'an. And yes it was still as oily. I didn't like this dish as much.I'll be back here often. I'm a sucker for noodle soups. They do run out of this so come early! Shortly after I ordered my food, they were announcing that there was no more! Seatings are limited. Just stand around by those tables to the right of the door and stare ppl down until they leave. J/K. Maybe not.

The aroma emanating from Very Fresh Noodles quickly caught our attention in the Chelsea Market. Watching the chefs toss and spin the noodles was both entertaining and fun. My two friends and I tried three different bowls. The Tawainese Beef Noodles were very flavorful in a broth of cilantro, chili oil, scallion and mustard greens. The noodles were gloriously thick and the slow-braised beef shanks were tender. The Tingly Cumin Lamb noodles were tasty as well and not overwhelmingly spicy. The Pork Spicy Dan Dan Mian noodles were creamy initially but then VERY SPICY. The broth was too oily. The Taro Bubble Tea was sweet, light and refreshing.

Tiny, tucked away food stand in Lord knows where in between 9th and 10th Ave on 15th St., this noodle shop is literally a hidden gem that have you sniffing your way in the deep, dark depths of the nooks and crannies in the maze we call Chelsea Market. There's no room to eat, you have to wait a long time, and you're going to be sad since they ran out of lamb, and they always run out of lamb. I suspect they do not even carry lamb because they seem to be out of it all the time. The cucumber salad was super small for what it costs but let's face it, there are many other places in CM but none can pull you in like their spicy and refreshing cucumber salad. The beef in the noodle soup was surprisingly tender so that's a plus. However, I've had better noodles in Chinatown and that's all I am saying.

Admittedly, I laughed when I saw this sign. Coming from a very Asian family, this is a very Asian name for a restaurant. "Very Fresh Noodles" would be the one who would have the last laugh, however. This was definitively one of the very best (and very freshest) meals that I had on my most recent trip to New York City.During my first visit to Chelsea Market, I was deeply embroiled in an internal battle as to where I would eat for lunch. Genuinely one of the hardest decisions I've ever had to make, as I was surrounded on all sides by the sights & smells of some of the most delectably unique restaurants I've ever seen in a market setting. I ended up standing in line for "Very Fresh Noodles" as I was extremely curious in Western Chinese cuisine, something that I'd never tasted before. I opted for the Tingly Cumin Lamb Noodles (dry). As the man behind the counter began pulling the fresh noodles by hand, I knew I had made the right decision.Honestly, I've never tasted anything like this dish in my entire life. Sure, there are flavors that are familiar, but the way they complemented & contrasted with the fresh noodles, sauces, and vegetables was altogether extremely new to me. I loved every bite, and I will undoubtedly order from here each time I patronize the Chelsea Market from here on out.Goofy name, perfect noodles. Do yourself a favor and wait it out with the crowd - it's worth it.

This place is delicious and the noodles are indeed, very fresh! Tucked in the corner of chelsea market, I didn't have any expectations but these noodles were amazing. I tried the tingly noodles- their best seller- in broth. The cashier recommended them to me over the dry noodles, so I went with it and the recommendation did not disappoint!The noodles are definitely on the salty side and are very oily. I was wearing a white shirt, so it got pretty messy. Be careful to eat these noodles slowly because they splash quite easily. The noodles themselves are so fresh, you can literally watch them make the noodles while you wait. The taste is a bit spicy, but also so full of flavor. The noodles really make you feel like you're at home. So authentic and would definitely recommend this to anyone.

The line was long and the noodles didn't look that good, so my friend and I skipped this at Chelsea Market in favor of Los Taco No. 1. BUT so many friends texted us to get their ~amazing beef noodle soup~ that we went back to try it. The first few bites were exciting because we knew we were eating something popular. The noodles were soft, the beef was quality and tender, the vegetables added a nice contrast, and the broth was spicy and delicious. BUT I couldn't eat more than half. The noodles were annoyingly too long, the cilantro was too strong, and the beef & broth quickly started to taste very oily and greasy. My friend ate more than me but couldn't finish it either. I would recommend this over other foods in Chelsea Market if you want to try something popular or if you've never had beef noodle soup before (the meat and broth are pretty quality). If you have a lower tolerance for grease, consider sharing one bowl with a friend. Also be aware that they add cilantro.

I don't care if it's "tourisy" to go to Chelsea Market. I love the food there. Let's put something in persoective: you have been on a train for 21/2 hours, you need to go to the bathroom, you are in NYC during the holiday season, you are on a subway with the whole population of Manhattan and the dude in the subway in front of you smell and you are HANGRY. What is going to make this situation better? That's right...good food.So, I read about this noodle place...and boy...was it amazing. Fresh, thick, long...get your mind out of the gutter people...NOODLES. Taiwanese style beef noodles....the broth was tangy..fresh bok choy with tender meat and home made thick noodles. This hit the spot...waiting in a crowded line, jam packed with people was worth it.From an operational perspective, they got this to a science. One person was deligated to one task creating an essembly line to get the dishes through fast without infringing on the quality. They wanted to let you know, they own their task and not have the task own them! The clear glass provided transparency in product quality and work quality. They had nothing to hide as they created soup perfection.They have a simple menu with few choices. Their game is noodle soups and they stick to what they know. They understand the market and their limitations. This is what a good business does and does it well. vfnoodles.comDon't knock Chelsea Market. It's got great restaurants and shopping for artsy, vintage pop up stores and sample sale stores. If you are the artsy type that like non commercial stuff, this is pretty good place for the occational local artist pop up stuff. Check out their website for special events: chelseamarket.com

Writing this review a bit late as my New York trip was in November and I stumbled upon this awesome noodle bar inside the Chelsea market. This was the best tasting noodles I've ever had in my life. I paired the beef noodle soup (can't remember the exact name) with the best tasting fresh soy milk drink I've ever had. Nothing can compare. As the other reviews have stated that there is an ingredient in the soup that will actually make your tongue go numb. I'm not sure what it was but at first I freaked out and thought I got an allergic reaction lol. I can't wait for my next trip to New York specifically because of this place. Only down side is the bar barely has any spots open and it's hard to find a place to sit down and enjoy.

After seeing the business insider video I decided to check it out during lunch time. I traveled from midtown to Chelsea. The wait was about 20mins for my order. I had the 牛肉麵 （Taiwanese beef noodle soup) the broth was very flavorful and the beef was so tender. It took me about 25 minutes to get back to the office so by the time I got to eat my soup the noodles were really soggy. I'd definitely go back and try again but this time I'll eat it at the Chelsea Market. FYI, you have to find a place to sit as the shop doesn't have tables. A quicker way to get in is to go up from 15st and 9ave. The shop is located towards the back of Chelsea market. Meal cost: $13

I was excited to try this place after seeing the video above it on social media. I'm a huge noodle person, especially Taiwanese beef noodle soup so I knew I had to try it. We got there at the perfect time Saturday around 11:30am because shortly after we ordered it started to get super busy and we saw pictures later that the line got super long. I ordered the Taiwanese beef noodle soup and my bf got the cumin beef noodle soup. I was surprised when someone had posted a review saying the portions were so big that they shared it with their friend and it was a good amount. Because I felt like they were normal portions and you definitely wouldn't be full if you shared one bowl between two people. I liked the noodles themselves but the soup I thought was a little too thick but still flavorful. The slices of beef were okay, a little on the thick side and I didn't like how every piece had so much tendon in it. My bf shared the same feedback except he didn't like the flavor of his cumin beef soup that much. All in all we thought it was okay but nothing super special.

The noodles are tasty but not worth the price. A lot of the shops in Chelsea Market are guilty of price gauging since it's a tourist mecca but $12 for a bowl of noodles and a few slices of lamb is kind of ridiculous. I would say that I liked the noodles here more than the ones at Xi'an Famous Foods since they have a bouncier texture but in terms of the lamb and the flavor, Xi'an wins by a mile. Xi'an's version tastes more tingly and more fragrant because of the cumin. The one here tasted more one dimensional. I would say it's worth a try if you're in the area and have never had this type of food before but there are definitely places out there that serve a better cumin lamb noodle soup without the hoards of tourists constantly ricocheting off of you in a too warm for comfort environment, even in the winter time.

This place is amazing! I suggest sitting in the window and watch the fresh noodles being made while you eat them. The process is lightning fast and enjoyable to watch. Oh yeah and the noodles are delicious.

I hate people who don't eat their noodle immediately or people who don't let me eat my noodle immediately. My third time here. The place was busy as usual. I patiently waited for my beef noodle soup. It took way too long. I saw my noodle was cooked and placed in the soup, wait to be add some toppings. It like a minute passed. Then, the guy who took orders were too busy taking new orders or flirting with customers. There were three bowls of noodle soup ready to pack and eat, instead the noodle just sit there and soak up the soup. By the time I finally get my bowl and ready to eat, the noodle weren't fresh anymore. It was very mushy. Where is my very fresh noodle?

The euphoric feeling after finishing a warm bowl of fresh hand-pulled noodles here is unparalleled. It's a different feeling entirely from finishing a bowl of pho, a bowl of soonduboo, a bowl of ramen, and deserves your undivided and immediate attention!We shared the cucumber appetizer (it was amazing to balance out the spiciness of the soup, as well), Lamb Tingly Cumin Noodle Soup, and Beef Noodle Soup. We could not stop closing our eyes in bliss with each bite. The beef was spectacularly tender; it is a work of art. The lamb is very thinly sliced and allows for maximal surface area contact. The noodles are a league of their own. All of this, combined, makes for a very special meal. Located in the maze of Chelsea Market where there are so many other food options, I cannot believe it took me so long to notice Very Fresh tucked away in their own little corner. Now this will be my first stop every time, not exaggerating. Stop reading and order already! :) Do not be discouraged if there seems to be a line forming when you visit. It goes pretty quickly, the staff is so efficient and fun, and the boba is sweet to sip on while you wait ;)

Wow! A must try in Chelsea market. This is a food stall that makes thick handmade noodles.  I had the beef spicy soup and it was really delicious. A little on the "fattier" oily side but so good and very different from other noodle soups I've tried. You can see through the window the fresh noodles they are making.The only downside is there very limited, almost no seating to enjoy the soup, so that made it a little difficult. But after waiting around for a bit, we snagged a seat on the only bench around.

Wow! They do live up to their name "very fresh noodles." Because they hand pull their noodles right in front of you and it's cooked when you put in your order so you know you're getting the freshest noodles. When you bite into their noodles you can definitely taste the freshness of their noodles, the texture is nothing I had ever tasted. Its chewy and thin; which is great because the noodles can soak up the broth. I ordered their La Mei Beef Noodle Soup and cleaver smashed cucumber. Their broth was very rich it was like sipping on a bowl on beef broth that's been simmering for overnight. Beef was so tender it separates right away without pulling, amazing. Their smashed cucumber was very oily, slightly sweet but very spicy but it was still delicious. Don't let the long line intimated you cus it moves quick. I waited roughly around 10-15 mins for my order on a weekend night.

I ordered the dan dan noodles, which were good but basically in a "soup" of chili oil, which added more of a greasiness and took away from the dan dan flavor. I LOVED the noodles though, they were perfectly cooked and they have a clear divider in front of the kitchen so you can see the employees hand pulling them. There isn't much seating area though as it is Chelsea Market.I would come again for the noodles but maybe something without as much chili oil (though most menu items have that)

I don't know why I've waited so long to write this review.I'm low-key proud of myself for going to VFN way before it was trending on Facebook/Instagram. The food is amazing and fresh - the noodles are so chewy and honestly, that's why I go back over and over again.The fact that they've grown from their small stall in Chelsea Market to essentially the entire left side of that back area is amazing. Now they can serve more customers (not running out of noodles anymore!) and there's a long countertop where you can stand and eat your delish noodles.The wait is a little long both to order and to get your food, but that's just the nature of trying to get amazing food in New York.Definitely give it a try!!

Delicious! When I came to town this was in my "must try" list. I stopped by Chelsea market around 2pm one day hoping to beat the crowd. Turns out they actually didn't open that day until 3pm as they spent the morning prepping (I think they might have moved to a new space?). Either way, I sat around and watched as the like grew from 10 to 20 to 30 couples long within an hour. I was super excited to order the lamb dish and it was delicious! Pretty oily and I don't recommend slurping down the soup, but the noodle was very filling and satisfying. I definitely want to try their dry noodle next time!

Went for lunch around noon on a Friday. Staff was friendly. The cashier was patient with us as my friend and I asked questions about the menu. He also made recommendations. I ended up with the Tingly Lamb. Dry, not the soup. I was a bit nervous b/c one of the ingredients of the dish is sichuan peppercorn. Last year I had the unfortunate experience of biting down on a whole one. If every you've done this, you know the taste and sensation is one that you can't forget. But, I was presently surprised with VF's Tingly lamb dish. Flavor: The flavor was WONDERFUL - very complex. A lot going on, but it all melds together for a party in your mouth.Spice level: Mild in terms of heat. Very spicy in terms of actual spices/herbs.Noodles: Perfect. Soft, chewy. LONGGG lol.Sauce: Pretty oily, but that's what type of dish this is. There spice-driven sauce is plentiful and coats every part of the dish... yaaassss.Lamb: Plentiful -- they don't skimp at all Tender, flavorful. I love that it is also seasoned and not just thrown in plain.Veggies: A decent amount. Crunch, fresh. Added a nice contrast to all the spices.Why not 5 stars? My dish was warm-ish when I received it. Not hot. Which is odd, because I watched them make it fresh and there was hardly a wait. Hopefully next time it'll be hotter!

I love the beef noodle soup it was so delicious. This place is hard to miss because you ca smell it as soon as you walk in the door  off 9th street and 15th street.
